item.description:
Taking on the roles of the kids from IT, in CLUE: IT players will move around the game board representing locations in and around the town of Derry, Maine to determine WHO Pennywise will abduct, WHAT object he will use to lure them, and WHERE he will take them from.

—description from the publisher

IT: Evil Below is a co-operative dice and card game that challenges all members of The Loser's Club to work together to drive Pennywise back into hibernation.

—description from the publisher

SetBack is the Buildable Board Game of strategy and chance that never plays the same way twice.

Shuffle the cards. Build the board. Deal each player a hand. Put your tokens on START and get ready — you’ve never played a game quite like this one.

The goal of SetBack is simple: be the first player to cross the FINISH line. To get there, you follow the cards. Each turn you’ll play a Board Action (the mandatory action of the card your token sits on), a Hand Action (one or more available options from the cards in your hand), and a Draw Action (replenish your hand from the draw pile).

Some cards are straightforward; they tell you exactly what to do. But most cards have options. Do you use the card to help yourself? Or burn your opponents? Wait – is there a way to do both? Of such is SetBack strategy born.

SetBack combines the portability of a card game with the playability of a board game to give it a fast-paced style where strategy shifts on the fly and the whole game can turn on the play of each card. Using the same cards to build the board AND your hand simplifies mastery of basic game mechanics while also resulting in millions of possible board configurations and unlimited replayability.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Anag-Run is a dexterity PnP game.

In the game, the players have to try to take the right tokens before the others, as soon as all letter of the 4 colors of the game (GOLD, RED, GREY and GREEN) are in the field.

But... attentive to the mole!!!

If the letters of word “MOLE” are on the field, when the letters of a colour appeared, you have to take all token, except the color on field!!!

You win a coin for each right tokens you take in round, but if you mistake, you lost all your coins!

When a player have 8 coins or all 14 coins have been distributed, the game ends. The player with more coins win!

—description from the designer

"Our last stronghold is under siege. Hundreds of evil minions are storming towards the castle. Our only hope depends on three mighty heroes... Three, against a huge horde..."

The heroes know, if they can maintain the castle long enough, when the sun will rise, the war will be over. 
But until that time they wil have to do whatever it takes to stop the enemy forces for as long as possible!

The Heroes of Ermaroda Castle - is a boardgame wich can be played solo or as co-op. You must survive for 18 rounds defending the castle. You choose 3 heroes who will help you to complete this achievement. Every round there will be an enemy-phase where minions move and also attack. The heroes-phase let you control your heroes who will have 3 actions each. The heroes will also have unique abilities and upgrades to stop the enemy. If after 18 rounds the castle still stands, you have won the game.

-description from designer

Each player is given 7 cards.
One player think of an answer that could be formed by a certain number of cards, show them to everybody to see and says a theme, other players have to find the answer.

Like Concept, but with cards instead of a board.

—user summary

The Colourable Words Game is a word based competitive family game of 2-4 players played over two phases. In the first phase, players try to score letters with the help of a D6 or D4 on a circular board. Each letter provides points as mentioned on the letter. The letters are divided in 6 colours and the phase enters its last round once a player manages to get letters in each colour. In the second phase players try to create a maximum of three words out of the letters they have scored, with each word providing points. Six letter words score bonus points. The second phase is completed once at least one player finishes putting down all three words. The player with the highest total points over two phases wins the game.

—description from the designer

All you need is ten cards, ten minutes, and one friend.

Fight Your Friends is a fast-playing, deck-dueling game that includes a cast of amazing characters from indie comics. Use thirty gold to build a hand (crew) of ten fighters (friends), then go head-to-head with a friend through four rounds of fighting. In each round, you secretly select a friend from your hand and match them against your opponent's. Through a paper-rock-scissors type of system, the friend with the best ratings in attack, magic, and defense wins the fight.

At the end of four rounds, you add up the gold value of your winning friends. If you end up with more gold than your opponent, you win!

Adult party game by the creators of What Do You Meme?

Shuffle up the cards, break into teams, and decide which team and player goes first.

During a round, play alternates between teams. One player on a team (the guesser) selects a card and places it on his/her forehead without looking at the words. A sand timer is flipped and the round begins with 60 seconds on the clock. Then other players must give clues to get the guesser to say the Buzz Word on the card. The tricky part is that each card displays four 4-Bidden words that you can't use for clues.

If they correctly guess the Buzz Word, keep going: grab a new card and keep playing until the timer runs out.

If a team member accidentally says a 4-Bidden word, a Penalty Chip is dealt. Penalty Chips subtract 1 point from your team's overall score. Aside from the 4-Bidden words, teams can also earn penalties for spelling out the words, rhyming, and acting things out.

Winning is based on how long a game you wish to play, 
Quick: Earn 10 points.
Normal; Earn 25 points
Marathon: Earn 100 points.

Contains 600 Buzz Words, 2,400 4-Bidden Words, 8 penalty chips, and a sand timer.

Rainbow is a trick-taking poker game with a unique 75-card deck of custom cards. The deck has no suits but instead is made up of 5 colors. Each color has 3 Aces, 3 Kings, 3 Queens, 3 Jacks, and 3 Tens.

Players are dealt 15 cards in each round. These cards are used to play 5 hands: a 1-card hand, a 2-card hand, a 3-card hand, a 4-card hand, and a 5-card hand. Players may organize their cards for the 5 hands in any order they desire. To win a hand a player must have the best cards at the table. Card value is determined by poker hands of the same color like pairs, 3-of-a-kinds, and straights with card color breaking ties (purple is the strongest color followed by blue, green, orange, and finally red.

Each round starts with betting to determine which player is risking points to predict how many tricks they'll win. The player who wins the most can win or lose the amount of points bet. The first player to 10 wins. Rainbow's unique rules make hand management and trick-betting fun and interesting.

—description from the publisher

All players are Zoo directors. In order to enhance the communications of different animals, everyone bring his/her own animals and communicate with other animals. Now, bring your animals and start communications...

Animals Friend is a party card game of guessing other's thinking.

Game play: 
Place the 11 different master animals as well as the round marker in the center of the table for reference for all players. Every player will get 11 different animals, 1 scoring card and 1 reference card. Every animal has a different scoring condition and provides different scores depending on how easily you can get it successfully. Every round, each player will send out one animal. After all players have sent out one animal, the scoring conditions of every animal are checked.

Game end conditions:
1. 10 rounds is completed
2. At least one player successfully got five animals scored.

There is another English name of the game called TamGu, which is the tranliteration of the Chinese name æ·¡å¤.

You are a group of tourists on a 3-day (72 hours) trip to Tamsui. In the game, you have to utilize limited time and money to visit the Monuments and taste the local food in Tamsui to gain "knowledge points". After finishing the game, the player with the most points will win the title of "Master of TamGu".
(This paragraph of description comes from the English rulebook.)

The game proceeds clockwise during the first round. On every turn the active player may choose either to visit a site or to earn money. To visit a site, the player chooses an available Traveling Card to buy (with both money and his limited time) and moves his pawn to the corresponding zone. If the player has insufficient money or he wants to gain the traveling fee, he can instead move back to the starting zone to convert any amount of time to money. After the first round, the game proceeds like the well-known game Patchwork.

The game continue till all players have moved for no less than 72 hours. The player with the highest knowledge points wins.

Poland Defiant was originally produced in limited quantities as “Plan West” by 3 Crown Games. Revolution Games has updated the game with new art, testing, and development.

Poland Defiant covers the first 10 days of the Polish campaign, September 1st to 10th, 1939. This was the period when the Polish armies met the German forces on the open terrain of Poland and the mobility and firepower of mechanized warfare was first demonstrated on a large scale. The Poles must hold on to key cities and the Germans must keep to a rapid time schedule, so the game is both balanced and tense.

Poland Defiant uses the same chit pull system and basic rules as Konigsberg with a few variations for the differences for this campaign. For example, the Germans have air interdiction and ground attack aircraft can launch attacks on units rather then just adding shifts to combat. Each turn is day and game play time is 6 to 10 hours.

Designed by Stefan Ekstrom

Components
1 - 22 x 34 inch map
1 - full counter sheet of half-inch counters
1 - rule booklet
1 - player aid
ziploc bag

-description from publisher

There are four volatile altcoins to bet on in the game: Ledginvest, Dodg-E-Coin, CryoCoin and Block Burster. Each altcoin has a corresponding stack of Market Cards that predict gains or losses. You need four players to be Investors to start the action. Each Investor gets two wallets and 10 physical Bitcoins. One Investor is also the Exchange Manager for the round. The Exchange Manager passes out one Insider Trading Card to each Investor and spins to see which altcoins will be open for trading that round. The Exchange Manager also secretly sets a timer for any time between 3 and 15 seconds so that only he or she knows how much time is on the clock for placing bets. Each Investor reveals their Insider Trading Card to the group to see what action they can take before the Market opens. You might even get an insider tip that gives you a competitive advantage in placing your bets. The Market is open! Investors simultaneously bet their Bitcoins on the altcoins by placing their wallets on the board. Trading immediately stops when the timer rings. The Exchange Manager then flips over the Market Card for each altcoin to reveal a gain or loss for each Investor. It’s Bitcoin boom or bust--one minute your wallet’s full and it’s Lambo time, the next second you lose everything in a scam! Keep playing until the Bitcoin Bank runs dry. The Investor with the most Bitcoin wins!

Contents: Includes: 160 Bitcoin, 12 Plastic Bitcoin Wallets, 1 Altcoin Speculation Mat, 1 Spinner, 40 Market Cards, 1 Exchange Manager Card, 4 Insider Trading Cards, 4 Character Cards, Instructions.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Forty Below is a card game where the goal is to score the fewest points, usually tallying the score over multiple fast-playing rounds.

The deck is comprised of eight copies of each number from -1 through 10, and four copies of -10.

In a given round, each player is dealt six face-down cards, which are then arranged in a 3x2 grid. Two of those cards are turned face-up. On a player's turn, he or she will do one of three things:

1. Flip a face-down card so the number shows
2. Draw the top card from the deck
3. Draw the top card from the discard pile

If either of the latter two happen, the player will have a choice: discard the just-drawn card, or replace one of his or her six cards with it (a replaced face-down card becomes face-up at that point).

This continues until one player has the numbers of all six cards showing. Play continues until everyone has an equal number of turns, and then they move on to scoring.

When scoring, if the top and bottom number of the player's grid matches (e.g. both a 7) then the numbers are negated and they become 0. Alternately, if a player can form a "square" of numbers - both top and bottom match on four consecutive spaces - then the player scores -40 points ---- they just went Forty Below.

Labyrinth 3D features gameplay familiar from the decades-old Labyrinth board game. The game board has a set of tiles fixed solidly onto it; the remaining tiles that make up the labyrinth slide in and out of the rows created by the tiles that are locked in place. One tile always remains outside the labyrinth, and players take turns taking this extra tile and sliding it into a row of the labyrinth, moving all those tiles and pushing one out the other side of the board; this newly removed tile becomes the piece for the next player to add to the maze.

Players move around the shifting paths of the labyrinth in a race to collect various treasures. Whoever collects all of his treasures first and returns to their home space wins!

What's new with Labyrinth 3D is that the game board has a 3D element, with players needing to go up and down levels as they travel through the maze, but a player can't jump more than one level at a time, so sometimes you'll be blocked from a treasure not due to a wall, but due to it being at the wrong height — or maybe you're at the wrong height. Either way, you need to figure out how to manipulate the maze to get the two of you together.

Note that Labyrinth 3D is not the same as 3D Labyrinth, which doesn't have a height element in the gameplay and which is aimed at younger audiences.

name.value: ESCAPE Dysturbia: Falsches Spiel im Casino

item.description:
The luxury casino of the rich tycoon Henrik de Graaf becomes the target of the syndicate's attack: In broad daylight an informant of the millionaire is shot in the lobby. Felicity Bale, the manager of the casino, asks for your help. The dead man was carrying a coded recording device that the syndicate was feverishly searching for.

Is there any incriminating material on the recorder to help you fight the criminal underground organization? There's little time left to find out. But be careful to keep your cards close to your chest! For the syndicate already is closer to you than you might think ...

Objective:

On the barren Planet of Gaia, players are Nature Spirits creating lush verdant lands, and giving rise to Life-Forms which come in three Species: CarniVores, HerbiVores, and Plants. But the swollen Moon, Vora, gazes hungrily from the night sky. It is jealous of Gaia’s life, and influences Species to eat each other!

The objective of the game is for your Life-Forms to:


 Eat the Life-Forms of your opponents,
 Survive to the end of the game without being eaten or killed.
 Stand on top of many layers of Tiles.


Gameplay:

Each turn, rotate the planet 2 steps. (Spend one of your three "Star Tokens" to rotate it 3 steps, or only 1 step. You never get any more Stars.) Whenever a Land Tile rotates to the position under the Moon, Eating occurs there: Herbivores eat Plants, and Carnivores eat Herbivores.

After rotating the Planet, choose one of the four corners of the board. The Sky Object printed there (Sun, Meteor, Rainbow, or Storm) will activate its ability on whichever location on the Planet has now been rotated beneath it. Life-forms are born under the Rainbow and the Sun, migrate out from under the Storm, and get blown up when the Meteor drops a Land Tile on them.

—description from the designer

A small, demo version of News@11 released prior to its Kickstarter campaign.

There are enough cards for 3 to 5 players to play 2 rounds, but you'll need a marker.

Contains 4 Segment cards, 8 Cue Cards & 1 instruction card.

The fill-in-the-blank cue cards allow players to customize game to their interests.

With the current Commodore lost at sea, you and your fellow Corsairs have set out to complete the traditional challenge – the first captain to sail the Valerian Isles and gather enough silver to fill six treasure chests will be the next Commodore. Seize the dice and roll, you scurvy Orc lover!

Coins earn you silver, Grog gives you the power to re-roll your dice, Cannons let you attack merchant ships or opponents to take their silver, and Maps move your ship forward. Watch out for the curses though, because each one you roll means a silver coin lost to Exekratys, or more commonly known as Skull Island to true Corsairs.

Your Captain card gives you a special player power that could help you win, if you use it to your best advantage.

The first player to reach Skull Island will get all of the coins lost to cursed dice, but if that doesn't fill your sixth treasure chest, the race resets and you keep on sailing. And, if you no Captain gains their sixth treasure by the second time someone reaches Skull Island, the game ends and the Captain with the most Treasure and Silver wins the game!

-description from publisher

Your goal in Monkey Duel is to accumulate points by leaping one's monkeys from bamboo stalk to bamboo stalk across the board. Monkeys that reach the opponent's side of the board score points. Knocking opposing monkeys off the board also scores points.

Players take turns rolling and exchanging dice in order to bring new monkeys onto the board, move their monkeys, or throw coconuts at opposing monkeys. Monkeys move in one of two ways, either climbing directly up their current bamboo stalk or leaping to the next one while dropping down one or more spaces in the process.

Monkey Duel is a game of positioning and timing. Monkeys positioned higher up the bamboo stalks hold an offensive advantage, but every move requires giving up some altitude. Monkeys can also keep one another safe, so deciding when to stick together and when to make an individual break for it is key to victory.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
18 Holes is a golf themed strategy game with a modular board and multiple ways to play. 18 Holes can be played solo, in teams or as 4-player versus match.

Players build the course as a social activity or use one of the pre-design courses that come with the game or are shared online by other players. The course layout then informs which clubs will work better and the players draft their hand from the deck of clubs. There are few duplicates in the deck and each club has a different ability.

Each turn, players use one of their club cards to access one or more shot decks. The shot decks contain cards that help the player move through the course. Each club can only be used once per hole forcing players to consider which club they use next. Not all shot cards go straight and there is no requirement for players to stay on course. Hitting off course on purpose allows players to press their luck in the hope of getting the advantage. The first player to navigate their way from the 1st green to the 18th wins.

A secondary game mode is Chaos Golf where each green is assigned a large and a small points token. Players can hit in any direction in an attempt to collect as many tokens as they can. The game ends when all large tokens have been claimed and the player with the most points wins.

-description from designer

Grand prix for small racers.

Every player selects a team (McLaren, Ferrari, Williams or Benneton) and tries to arrive to the finish line as quickly as possible. A race lasts for 1, 2 or 3 laps. A player rolls a die and moves his car for the given number of spaces.

Velika nagrada za male dirkaÄe.

Vsak igralec izbere svoje moštvo (McLaren, Ferrari, Williams ali Benetton) in poskuša Äim hitreje priti s svojim avtom do cilja. Dirka traja 1, 2, ali 3 kroge. Igralec vrÅ¾e kocko in premakne svoj avto za toliko polj kot jih pokaÅ¾e kocka.

—user summary

Squirrel is a family friendly game of tactical foraging. To win you must gather the biggest hand of acorns before the last leaf of Autumn turns brown.

The game starts with a grid of 9 green leaf piles. Under each green leaf card is a chance to find either a brown leaf or 1 to 3 brown acorns.

Players must each build a maximum hand of 3 cards by hopping their squirrel counter from one leaf pile to the next. After each move they must take 1 card from the top of a neighboring leaf pile to add to their hand.

If their hand exceeds 3 cards or they make a gap in the grid, they must drop a card with its brown side face up. In this way the leaf piles change color from green to brown and when the top card of all 9 leaf piles shows a brown face, the game (and autumn) has ended. Players must then reveal their hands and the player with the greatest total number of acorns is the winner.

Beware. 
The best foragers may be pushing their luck. A squirrel who holds more than 3 acorn cards must drop one in plain view. An opponent who stands on a dropped acorn can steal from your hand! 
Wise foragers can manage their hand as well as the length of the game by choosing when to voluntarily drop a card and which green leaf piles to cover or reveal.

Squirrel has enough gameplay for adults and older children to enjoy with enough luck to keep young children in the game without constantly feeling out-maneuvered.

-description from designer
Salad of worms is a tile based game where the players place tiles in order to construct worms of different colours from tail to nose.

name.value: Charged Canada: Electric Vehicle Mission-Based Strategy Board Game

item.description:
Charged Canada is an electric vehicle mission-based board game. Charged Canada brings you back to a not too distant past where there are no charging stations across the entire nation. It's up to you and your friends to decide where to put the charging stations as you see fit with your missions.

Missions include traveling from a specific city to city, collecting resources, and building charging stations or solar installation. Each player receives their own mission cards at the beginning of each game playthrough. With hundreds of mission cards to choose from, your three starting missions are not going to be the same as the other players.

Each round is determined using the actions cards, which can be used right away or held for later use.

Strategy game elements include:
map building
deck building
point to point movement

With multiple ways to win, typically through completing a mission card for the victory point on that card. Another way is to create charging stations or solar installations to earn a victory point for each.

The first one to the victory point limit wins. The VP limit is dependent on the number of players as Charged Canada can have up to 8 players. The higher the number of players the lower the VP limit.

Each playthrough will be different based on the mission cards that everyone has and decides how to proceed with those missions.

Charged Canada is easy to learn and play for even the most beginner to board games.

-description from designer

The subtitle "Die Maus (the mouse)" is from a children TV series. 
The mouse is only on the cover and on each side of the cards, therefore not really part of the game play.
There are 5 round cards, with each 16 different images on both sides.
The images are from different categories (animals, fruits, clothing, vehicles, ...)
These 5 cards are placed in the middle of the table. The player who finds first the image which is on all 5 cards (allways exact 1) gets a chip of his choice.
The 5 cards are new placed (turning some of the cards) and a new round starts.
If a player has 4 equal chips he wins the game.

Welcome to Jurassic World, a miniature wargame from 2 to X players.
Choose a scenario and your army of dinosaurs or heroes from the movie saga. Build your decks of action and hero cards accordingly.

Feel the thrill of brutal combat between dinosaurs using unique and cinematic action card mechanics. Plan your actions by placing cards in sequence while guessing your opponent's ones. 
Alter effects or sequence by well-timed hero cards to tilt the tide of battle in your favor.

—description from the publisher

The dream couple is being sought for a theater project or the school sport championships. Find the best matching pairs for specific events. Romance, sportiness, popularity and interests / talents play the most important roles in the right combination of the dream couples. Jokers influence the gameplay and do not allow pairings to arise or change them in unexpected directions.


 6 playing cards - 3 boys and 3 girls cards - are issued to each player
 3 event cards are laid open
 Players take turns taking a card to an event and reloading a new card
 the player who completes the pair to the event receives the cards
 Joker cards (suspend, blockade, veto) can affect the game for your own benefit
 the game ends when all event cards have been played
 the player with the most points wins the game


—user summary

We are currently observing the largest construction boom in Poland since the reconstruction after World War II. These days not storks but steel cranes are characteristic Features of Polish landscape.

The players are directors of large construction companies. The companies succeeded in winning numerous tenders and divided Poland into several areas of operation. Each player hurries to perform tasks in several voivodeships, since Polish people and business need new roads and bridges.

This is a 5 Minute card game. you have a have a hand of 6 cards. you play higher and high until someone can't play and they get those cards to a pile to be counted later for scoring. play is over rounds until the deck is gone. then game is over and hands left are discarded into pile to be counted. cards 1 to 13, with 2 different wild cards per deck. This game is 1 to 4 player, but 2 decks can be put together to make it 8 players.

—user summary

Wordsmith is all about building words, but instead of whole letters, you have letter pieces in four different shapes. All players create words simultaneously using each piece to avoid losing points in this fast-paced, real-time word building frenzy.

Trumps & Ladders is a trick-taking party game.

A new party game that takes a humorous spin on a divisive political subject - the border wall. The game is simple & similar to spades. The first player lays down anything they want, and players must follow suit. If a player cannot follow suit, he may play a ‘Trump’ or lose the round. The hand is won by the player who has the highest ‘Trump’ or ‘immigration’ card.

—description from the publisher
In Dragon Market, players attempt to manipulate boats on a river in order to pick up the items they need to complete contracts and score points.

A simple game where the British and Continental armies move around a board to capture enemy pieces, place their flags signifying the capture of key locations, then move on the enemy's capital to capture it an win the game.
The game can also be won by destroying the enemy army. Movement is by die roll. the pieces are designated as infantry, cavalry and cannon and have differing qualities. The rules are one page, and is vaguely reminiscent of the American Heritage series game Battle Cry.

—description from the publisher

Echek is a chess-inspired game which is played with only 12 cards and without an actual board.
Each player has 6 pieces (King, Queen, Root, Bishop, Knight and Pawn) with chess-like moves and they play on a 4x4 virtual square.
The game begins with both Kings face to face, and each turn players can move a piece or put a piece into play.
The game ends when a King is surrounded by 4 pieces.

—user summary

The city of Thera was destroyed around 1600 BCE by a volcanic eruption the size of which had not been seen for 10,000 years. Thera’s strategic location along the trade routes of the Mediterranean has made for a lucrative opportunity to rebuild the city. You are not the only one to recognize this.

Use your resources wisely to clear away the ash, establish a vibrant economy, and build temples and monuments as you compete with other patricians and nobles to rebuild Thera so that it will stand the test of time.

On a player's turn they choose one of five roles. All players have access to the role's primary benefit and the player whose turn it is gets additional benefits. The 5 roles allow players to generate and trade resources, clear away ash (which slows down resource movement), move the resources to building sites, and build industry and luxury buildings:


 The Priest causes water to rain from the sky.
 The Worker uses that water to hydrate workers as they produce resources.
 The Planner moves these resources to the areas that need them (resources must be located in the site on which a building is to be constructed).
 The Builder uses goods and money to build buildings and clear ash from the streets.
 The Trader trades goods and money around, allowing the island access to goods it might not have enough of.


Players earn victory points from the buildings constructed. Additional points can be earned by constructing buildings in prime territory (for example building temples among the coastal mountains or wineries in the lush valley).

—description from the publisher

name.value: 海賊の宝島 ～オクラコーク～

item.description:
æµ·è³Šã®å®å³¶ ï½žã‚ªã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚³ãƒ¼ã‚¯ï½ž is a trick taking game. The goal is to collect the most treasure in multiple rounds.

There are 36 cards in 4 suits, each with 9 cards from 1 to 5. Some cards will have a treasure with them. Each player will have 4 rum tokens at the beginning. Each player is dealt 4 cards. During each trick, players have to follow the lead suit. In case a player cannot follow, he draws a card and place it face down in front of him, which he will take it into his hand. (A playerr can also intentionally pass to draw one more card.) Otherwise, the player who plays the highest card wins the trick. He places the collected treasures (on the card) in front of himself. In case of a tie, the card with skull wins the trick.

When a player empties his hand, he escapes. When two players escape, the round ends. If a player escapes without collecting 3 treasures, he is punished for being a coward. He turns over a rum token to chicken token. If a player escapes with 3 or more treasures, he get a score equal to the number of collected treasure. For other players who cannot escape, they will be caught by the navy and lost a life (rum token).

The game ends when (i) a player has over 15 scores, or (ii) all players lost their last life. In case (i), the winner is who collected more treasures. In case (ii), everyone loses.

—user summary

ã‚¸ãƒ£ãƒ³ã‚­ãƒ¼ is a trick-taking game for 3p. There are 25 cards: 1-24 (with either dark or white chocolate) and a score card.

8 cards are dealt to each player. At each trick, the second highest players wins the trick and leads next trick. After 8 tricks are played, the players score based on the difference of the collected dark and white chocolate. The game ends at a round when a player gets more than 8 score. The player who has the highest score wins. If there is a tie, the player who is loudest wins.

—user summary

Train to Zakopane is an economic game in which players for eight rounds place their representatives on the action track and perform various action, such as taking raw materials, exchanging raw materials, investments in infrastructure construction, construction of the Zakopane railway and a court trial for Morskie Oko. The action track, which runs around the board, allows players to occupy any field, except that employees cannot go back to the fields they have missed. At the beginning of each round in order of players, they choose one of the available bonuses. After each round, players earn a profit from their investments and victory points.

—description from the designer

Pakal is a real-time sliding-puzzle game in which each player has a 4x4 grid filled with 15 blocks, some of which have a solid color on them and some of which are clear.

Each round, an objective card is revealed, then players slide their blocks in their grid, trying to show only the symbols on that card in their grid and hiding any other symbols from view. If you do this before time runs out, you can grab one of the available scoring blocks, then move your token on the scoring track to the next such symbol on the track. Thus, the quicker you solve the puzzle, the more likely you are to grab a block that advances you the farthest.

Whenever you cross a red line on the scoring track, you must replace a colored block in your grid with a clear one, thereby making it more difficult for you to solve objective cards in future rounds.

In Ring of the Temple, players collectively try to reinforce crumbling towers that contain gods because their safety depends on those gods staying put.

The circular game board is made of three sections representing the towers, and the board is circled by a number of action and resource cards. On a turn, players take turns placing their wizard on a card, then they collect all the resources on their location as well as all locations left and right of them until they hit another figure or the guard. They then use these resources to advance their marker in the towers or power gears on their personal player board that give them special abilities.

In the two-player game Watergate, one player represents the Nixon administration and tries not to resign before the end of the game while the other player represents The Washington Post and tries to show the connections between Nixon and some of his informers.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Meet the Manchers is a game in which each player is a family member from the Manchers family, who are about to have their traditional Sunday feast. Some families go to church, some families take picnics, the Manchers have their Sunday feast. Many dishes will be cooked, not everyone will try them all, because this is not a quiet family dinner oh no, it is more of a race filled with many flavors and nutrition accompanied with the occasional duel for table dominance. However, rules must still be obeyed, table manners are important, the nicest member will be praised and will get a reward, the naughtiest member will be scold and left to do the dishes. Eating tasty food is important, but more so are the flavors and nutrition. Will you be the one who will accomplish all three, or be stuck with dishes…

—description from the publisher

item.description:
The Menace Among Us is a thrilling semi-cooperative game of intrigue and survival in deep space. Adrift and powerless, your crippled vessel is bleeding oxygen. As you effect repairs, every breath you take brings you one step closer to death. You must work together to restore power before the air runs out… but hidden among you, as loyal friends and crewmembers, are imposters who have infiltrated security and continue to sabotage the ship. Their only goal is to avoid detection and kill the crew, by force or by asphyxiation. Can you identify them in time and eliminate the threat? Or will succumb to The Menace Among US?

The Menace Among Us is a 40 to 60-minute, asymmetrical card game for 4-8 players. Each player chooses an Agenda at random, either a loyal Crew member, a deadly Menace or the Coward, who’ll take any side just to survive. Your Agenda card sets a Team Goal and an Individual Goal, as well as outlines any special abilities and the card composition of your individual 13-card deck. Then, knowing your Agenda and Goals, you choose a Character who you believe will best help you achieve them or mask your true identity. Characters add 7 new cards to your deck, shuffle-building a unique combination of cards, as well as provide you two specialized Above Deck Actions.

In this hidden traitor game, how you play your cards and abilities is far more important than the meta game aspects of accusations and denials. Cards are played face down and shuffled together as “Below Deck Actions.” Here, Menace players secretly sabotage the ship’s systems and attack crew members, who are trying to save the ship with their cards. If too few crew members risk going below deck to effect repairs, the ship’s Emergency Maintenance Assistant (EmMA) adds cards to the pile to help. However, the system has also been compromised and occasionally places damaging cards into the mix, providing plausible deniability to the Menace players. In contrast, Above Deck Actions are conducted in full view of the crew. Most of these abilities have costs, either in Energy or Oxygen, both resources the crew is trying to increase. So, while The Doctor has the ability to heal a crew member and remove a debilitating effect, a Menace player, who may be secretly in control of The Doctor, cares far more that it costs 2 Oxygen to perform the healing.

At some point, someone’s behavior will raise suspicion. But, did they do so because they are trying to fulfill an Individual Goal – or are they a Menace? You can call a vote to expose their true nature. But if they are a loyal Crew member, you’ve just blown precious Oxygen in the effort to detain them. For that matter, was it a Menace player calling the vote in hopes of wasting the air on purpose?

If the Crew can find and eliminate the Menace players – and raise the Energy to a safe threshold before the air runs out, they win. If the Menace can prevent this or kill the crew outright, their mission succeeds. Special commendations are awarded for surviving and for achieving your Individual Goal.

-description from publisher

item.description:
Grand Sumo is a 2-player card game based on the 1,500 year old sport of sumo wrestling, in which you will be programming your wrestler’s actions through card play and aim to either push you opponent out of the ring, or wrestle him to the ground.

Like real sumo bouts, you can attempt to attack aggressively in hope of a quick victory, or try to outwit and outlast your opponent.

Each bout in Grand Sumo consists of 3 contacts, where you will simultaneously program your wrestlers' actions by playing cards face down in front of you. When both players are ready, the cards are revealed one at a time, and resolved as pushing, wrestling and defensive actions in the ring.

The player who manages to push or rotate the wrestlers token to meet a winning condition wins the bout, and the first player to win 3 bouts will be crowned the winner of Grand Sumo.

-description from designer

Zany Zoo is a 2-player card drafting game, where you play as zoologists gathering creatures that emerged from another dimension, and taking care of them.

The game is played over 3 rounds, where 5 multi-use cards are dealt to each player per round, from which you will draft 4 for a total of 12 cards. You will then utilize 1 of the 3 functions of these cards to either build your creatures, feed them or clean up their wastes to score victory points.

You decide which strategy to adopt as there are a few ways to score victory points. Manage your sanctuary well to score more victory points than your opponent and be recognized as the ‘best zoologist of the third dimension’!

-description from designer

MythMash is a worldbuilding and story generation game, in which players draw prompts and improvise a vibrant narrative together. It's simple rules and sandbox style make it a versatile too for planning character backstories, lore and questlines. It can also be used as a real time campaign aid/randomisation tool for RPGs such as DND and Everyone's John.

—description from the designer

Pangea is a strategic board game set in the time of the Great Permian Extinction. Back then, at the end of Perm, life on Earth was on the brink of utter extinction.

Over the course of the game, each player manages a particular species and tries to prepare it for the imminent catastrophe by adaptation to a changing environment as well as fighting other species.

item.description:
A set of revised and expanded wargaming rules for the exceptionally popular post-apocalyptic vehicle game, Gaslands.

Shoot, ram, skid, and loot your way through the ruins of civilization with Gaslands: Refuelled, the tabletop miniature wargame of post-apocalyptic vehicular mayhem. With all new material including expanded and enhanced perks, sponsors, vehicle types, and weapons. Gaslands: Refuelled contains everything a budding wasteland warrior needs to build and customize their fleet of vehicles in this harsh post-apocalyptic future. Featuring a host of options for scenarios, environmental effects, and campaigns, allowing players to create their anarchic future.

In the late Middle Ages, northern Europe is dominated economically by an alliance of cities known as the Hanseatic League. Its central city, Lubeck, enjoys such prosperity that it has come to be called the Queen of the Hansa.

In The Queen of Hansa, you are a Lubeck merchant who seeks to acquire more wealth than any other through trade with other cities in the League.

In this 2-4 player game your goal is simple: win a $1,000 hand of blackjack at Casino Reno and win the game. Along the way you'll gamble, bluff, buy, and bet to avoid being left penniless in the desert.

Players move around the game board by pulling cards from the top of a draw pile. They can also bet on these movement cards to make money and win action cards. The spaces on the board offer opportunities to gain asset and action cards, gamble in casinos, and play poker against other players. Avoid losing money when players gamble in your casino and manage to make money when you gamble in other players' casinos and you'll be in Reno before you know it!

—description from the publisher

You have found a strange device working on the energy of a rare elastic substance known as "Kauchukium". The device bends time and space and allows you to travel to foregone and yet undiscovered worlds in search of amazing treasures — but you are not the only one lurking among ancient ruins or looking for jungle temples, so don't drag your feet, choose the best tactics, and be the first to band the world!

Kauchuk is an area-control game in which players claim territory by enclosing it with elastic bands, building from an edge of the board and from territory that they already control. Travel to eight locations using a unique 3D game board and components. The rules of the game change from one location to another, providing players with a variety of experiences.

Ring of Stones is a fun and easy game that can be played with one or two players. For one player, see how fast you can build the ring of stones and compete against your friends for the best time. For two players, take it in turns to roll the dice to add or dismantle pieces of the circle. The one who completes or clears the board is the winner.
It consists of a circle of stones that replicates the design of Stonehenge’s outer sarsen circle.

—user summary

An intense cooperative, dice-rolling, unique tower defense set in a medieval fantasy world for 1 to 4 players. Have you ever wanted to be an archer on a castle wall? Now is your chance because all players play as archers defending against four powerful armies all attacking at once. Will the small band of archers defend the great castle of Godfrey or will the four Captains of the armies gain control of the castle? It is up to you and your team of archers so, “Notch, Draw, Loose!”

How To Win:
Players win if all four Captains are killed before one reaches the Center of the Keep.

Players lose if:
>> A Captain reaches the Keep at the center of the Inner Court. 
>> All ten soldiers of any one army are placed on their quadrant in the bailey.
>> The Player’s Deck has no more cards left to draw.

General Gameplay:
The goal of the game is to kill all 4 Captains before 1 advances to the Keep. Archers will be attacking the Captains with their arrows while eliminating the invading armies. Players will also use cards and purchase items from the Archer’s Equipment to accomplish this goal.

Every normal arrow is worth 1 damage unless otherwise stated on the cards or with special abilities. Each archer has 5 arrows and 5 spaces to move each turn.

The 12mm dice are the soldiers of the different armies that are invading the castle. The health of a soldier is determined by what it rolls. Archers can ONLY attack soldiers in their row of their quadrant. Archers kill soldiers with their arrows by reducing the soldier’s health down to 0. Archers receive an Archer Trophy for each soldier they kill during their turn. Archers will use these trophies to purchase equipment to help them defeat the Captains.

When a soldier's health reaches 0, then remove that dice from the bailey and place it back on its army’s card in the Gathering Area. The soldier dice will be rolled again and placed in a future round.

Archers do NOT receive an Archer Trophy if soldier dice are killed while being placed during the Enemy phase. However, Archers do earn trophies for soldier dice killed by barrels and cards that upgrade their arrows.

Most of the cards are split and have two options. Players choose one option to play and then discard. Players CANNOT play both of the options on the split cards. Split cards are designed to help for the different situations that players find themselves in.

Each round has two phases: Archer Phase and Enemy Phase.

Archer Phase
Each Archer Phase consists of all 4 archers taking their turns.

Player’s Turn:
Draw 1 Card 
Add to hand or follow the instructions if it is an Enemy Card. “Captain Advance” cards advance the Captain to the next space in their trail toward the Keep at the center of the Inner Court.
“Extra Soldier” cards will add an additional soldier to be placed during the Enemy Phase of that round (

2) Anytime during an archer’s turn they may:
Move 5 spaces and Shoot 5 arrows.
Play 1 card from your hand OR purchase items from the Archer's Equipment
If you purchase items, then you CANNOT play a card in the same turn.
If you play a card, then you CANNOT purchase items in the same turn.

3) Discard for hand limit
4) Pass the 1st player Castle Token to the person on your left (Clockwise)

Player’s Movement:
Archers are allowed to move to any space along the castle walls with a yellow border. Only one archer is allowed on each space along the wall. However, two archers may be on a “Starting Position” at the same time while they are moving along the wall. And as archers move past another archer, they CANNOT shoot arrows in the row of the other archer as they pass over them.

Stairs do not count as a space, the Archers just walk through them to the next space with a yellow border. Start positions do count as one space when the Archers are moving around to the other wall.

Enemy Phase
Each Enemy phase begins immediately following the Archer Phase. 
The Enemy Phase consists of 3 elements:
Roll the d8 Captain dice and resolve.
Check what number you rolled with the Roman numerals on the 4 corner towers. Whatever number you rolled, the Captain in that quadrant advances one space.

If the Captain is in the bailey,then add a rolled soldier in the space that the Captain advanced from.

If the Captain is in the Inner Court, then resolve any Barricades that they might have passed through. No soldiers are ever placed in the Inner Court.

If that Captain is dead, then nothing happens. Take a deep breathe. You DO NOT re-roll if you rolled to advance a dead Captain.
Roll the Soldier Placement dice for each of the 4 armies and place 2 soldiers on to each quadrant of the bailey.

Roll 8 new soldiers (2 for each army) and place them on the two soldier positions of their army card. These will be placed in the next round during the Enemy Phase.
The highest health is placed in position #1
The lowest health is placed in position #2

After rolling the NEXT soldiers and placing them on their army cards, then the Archer Phase of the next round begins

Aliens exist! But what will you do with that knowledge?

In Men In Black: Undercover, you play as a member of three different groups with three very different goals. The Men In Black are a secret organization who supervise alien activity on Earth and work to keep their existence hidden from the general population. Meanwhile, members of the Shadow Government are doing everything in their power to capture aliens and weaponize them. Lastly, there are the Conspiracy Theorists who are working toward proving the existence of aliens to the world.

Which side will come out on top? That's where you come in! Join a team and influence the aliens to join your cause, but make sure you aren't too obvious with your goals. After all, you'll need to stay undercover to win...

Debunked is a highly strategic card game of logic, reason and nonsense! There are two decks, one full of fallacious arguments, and the other full of everything else - which includes logic to debunk the arguments, ways to improve your hand (such as resurrecting a card from the discard pile), and, most importantly, ways to mess with your opponent (such as making them skip their go). It’s very simple to learn, but hard to master… like logic itself.

There are 2 decks, 1 full of fallacious arguments, and 1 full of everything else. Place 1 argument in the middle and then deal 5 cards to each other.

On your turn you can play as many cards as you like. For example, you could debunk two of the fallacies committed by the argument, discard a card from your opponent, and make your opponent skip their turn. Opponents may have cards which burn your logic or block your actions.

Once the argument is fully debunked, players receive one point per fallacy they successfully laid, plus 1 point for the player who finished the argument, and then the next argument is placed in the middle (giving the player who finished the previous argument first dibs).

The game ends when there are no more arguments to debunk, and the sweet song of reason finally echoes peacefully. The player with the most points wins and the player with the least points believes in anything and everything!

In hexaGONE, players take turns placing hexagons from their hand with the intention of creating hexagon sequences which match one of the face up Sequence Cards. The more complicated the sequence, the more the Sequence Card is worth. If a player manages to match a sequence, that player collects the Sequence Card, scores the points listed on the card, and a new Sequence Card is drawn. The player with the most points at the end of the game - as determined by the sum of his or her Sequence Cards - is the winner.

hexaGONE is sort of like abstract Scrabble. Instead of creating words (and then losing a friendship over an argument about whether yex is a real word) players strive to create sequences which match any of the various face-up Sequence Cards. The sequences on the Sequence Cards range from simple 4-hexagon sequence to more complex, longer ones.

Special-Play hexagons add variety to the game by allowing players to do more than just place hexagons onto the board. Here are some of the Special-Play hexagons included in hexaGONE:

Swap-agon: swap the positions of any two hexagons on the board.
Draw-agon: immediately draw 2 hexagons. You may exceed your hand size limit for this turn only.
Move-agon: move one hexagon on the board to a new location
Bomb-agon: remove a face up Sequence Card then you may immediately draw a new one

name.value: Embers of Memory: A Throne of Glass Game

item.description:
Aelin Galathynius has given up her freedom for the sake of her people. Held captive by the Queen of the Fae and tortured for information, her only companions are a silent prisoner and her own mind. The image of her mother, her lover, her friends. The embers of her memory, and a voice, deep inside...

"You will not yield."

Embers of Memory: A Throne of Glass Game is a two-player co-operative card game set during the events of Kingdom of Ash, the epic climax to Sarah J. Maas' Throne of Glass series. Working together, you must delve into the memories of the young queen and help her face her inner demons before she is overwhelmed. Be warned — each challenge you face is more complex than the last, testing the bond between you and your partner to its limit.

—description from the publisher

Chess Unbound is a two-player game based on traditional chess. The unique concept in Chess Unbound is that each piece's movement is indicated by the space it occupies on the chessboard. Each space on the game board contains a modular tile that shows a movement style from traditional chess (pawn, knight, rook, etc.). When you move a piece, follow the movement style on its current space. When the piece comes to rest, the space it lands on will indicate how it moves next turn.

The object of the game is to capture your opponent's king. The king piece is the only unique piece in the game, in that it never follows the movement rules of the spaces it occupies (it only moves like a king in traditional chess).

—user summary

Paragon Studio's flagship game, Soulbound is a strategic battle card game experience unlike any other before it. Utilising the "everything in one box" model, everyone who plays Soulbound will be able to experience the game as it is intended to be, without the financial investment hurdle. Feel the thrill of commanding creatures of mythology to become the next Soulbound!

Along with creatures of mythology, Soulbound introduces a unique take on explaining what happened to these creatures that stoppped their existence in Modern Day planet Earth. Explore how the unknown war of the heavens and hell, known as "The Vanishing", caused Pandora's Box to thrust creatures of mythology and Gods alike into an alternate reality of planet Earth, known as Axiom07 by the greater beings. To the local population, the planet is called Duhra, and they have no idea about the darkness that they will have to fight back in order to survive.

Soulbound is the world's first battle card game that gives you the authentic Trading Card Game experience, while incorporating a heavy influence from Tactical Turn-Based Strategy Role-Playing games and a "Dynamic Resource" system. With Melee creatures, Ranged creatures and Support creatures, players will get to make new kinds of tactical decisions.

Every game of Soulbound comes with every card available. It also comes with two starter decks pre-configured so that players can learn that game before jumping in to the deck building aspect. In a box, 2 players can easily create two competitive decks. For the most competitive players, they may find they need a copy of the game for their own. With an abundance of available cards to build decks from, your ability to make the correct tactical decisions will be the biggest difference in a game. Skill should always determine the best player, not the player with the deepest pockets.

Soulbound is played over a series of turns in which you, an Animan of the planet Duhra, command creatures in battle against other Animan to work your way up to the title of "Soulbound" and be entrusted with fighting back the darkness that escaped from Pandora's Tome. Utilising your own Soul Energy, you begin your turn by building up your resource to Call creatures to the field. Creatures are able to act the turn they are played to the field which creates a very high tempo game. Having a strong offence is just as important as having a strong defence, as your resource also acts as your life force. Throughout a game, it can be attacked and fluctuates because of that. No linear resource growth here.

Through the many creatures' abilities and combat, players attempt to make tactical decisions to break through the opponent's defences and deal damage to the opponent's resource. A skillful players will be able to manage both their own resource and their opponent's resource to ensure they always can have the upper hand.

With outstanding table presence, outstanding art, and outstanding gameplay, Soulbound will keep you engaged and constantly creating new combos in your head. In the end, the only thing that matters is dealing 60 Soul Damage to your opponent and claiming your spot among the Soulbound.

—description from the publisher

The radioactive dust of the Last War has left the northern countries frozen. In the ice desert, the few survivors live in a nice little hell: the resources of the “old world” are now exhausted, and traveling to the south is too long and dangerous. But a radio message is rekindling hope: the last icebreaker ship, the Aurora, is cruising along the coast, looking for survivors. In only a few days, those who cannot get on board the ship will be doomed by the ice. It will be a race against time: to make it to the ship or surrender to despair. There’s still the light of hope on the horizon—a light to grab before it’s too late!

Last Aurora is a post-apocalyptic game for 2-4 players set in a frozen, desolate land. Each player has to manage their crew to gather resources, recruit survivors, improve their vehicle, and fight their enemies as they race to reach the ship before it’s too late!

GAMEPLAY
The game is structured in 6 rounds divided in 5 phases:

exploration
you can collect cards and resources from a common zone. In particular you can use survivors to:
a) collect resources from a location card (FOOD: useful to power up survivors and/or to reuse them faster FUEL: used to move on the map AMMO: used to shoot enemies);
b) upgrade the vehicle / hook a trailer / install a device;
c) hire a new survivor (each one has a unique special ability, useful in a specific phase);
d) resolve an encounter card (example: trade item and resources with a merchant);

rest
you recover the survivor used (a survivor generally need to rest 1 turn to be ready for another exploration, but you can spend food to make them immediately re-available)

movement
you can move the truck on the map spending fuel (the distance depends on the number of fuel cubes spent, the speed of the vehicle, items, special abilities...).

fire
you can use weapons to shoot near enemies to gain fame and loot special cards.

end or round
the ship moves away and players prepare the next round.

The game end when one player reach the ship or at the end of the last round.

END OF THE GAME
The winner is determined by fame points, calculated on different things (advantage on map, fame points collected, items, abilities).
In addition, there are extra points based on the result of the game:
a) if a player reached the ship, all players must add fame points for every sane survivor rescued.
b) if no one has been able to stop the Aurora, players calculate extra fame points based on their vehicle cards.

This duality doesn't allow players to know the exact number of victory points during the game. 
This aspect makes every game full of tensions and directly involve players to speed up the vehicle and make important choice, like they really are running to save their life.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
I'm Going Down (IGD) is a print-and-play solitaire game about survival deep in enemy territory.

You play as a Pilot whose attack aircraft has been shot down during a routine mission. Now, you have to evade enemies and survive the elements long enough to scrounge together a search and rescue beacon to summon help. Your time on the ground will not be easy. The odds are against you.

You may also be able to turn your misadventure into heroism if you can capture enemy intelligence, destroy some of their installations, or maybe find other MIA allies and return to safety with them.

Or maybe you'll get eaten by a bear while trying to hide from a storm in a cave.

IGD is a solitaire game driven by tables and cards. Inspired by games like Ambush! and Ranger, you will see the narrative of your Pilot's exploits unfold in front of you through a combination of cards drawn and tables rolled on. Careful planning and choices will be pitted against the vagaries of fate, and the wide range of available Event cards mean games can feel drastically different from one another. One game will be a ruthless hunt as you flee from dogged pursuers, another may be a battle against rains, wildfires and errant bombing runs, and the next may see the tables turned as you attack enemy installations with captured weapons.

—description from the designer

Pigs-R-Poppin' There's no stoppin.' Ready, aim, launch your Pig-o-nauts into the orbiting Sty-in-the-Sky. All pigs in, you win!

Pigs-R-Poppin' consists of 16 soft rubber Pig-o-nauts, 4 brightly colored launching shuttles, and one Sty-in-the Sky space station. Players launch their Pig-o-nauts from the spring-loaded arms on their shuttles, aiming for docking bays in the Sty-in-the-Sky space station. To make their task more difficult, the Sty-in-the-Sky is constantly moving, turning on a single rubber tire at bottom of the space station. The first person to land 4 pigs safely into their docking bay wins.

name.value: Valley of the Kings: Premium Edition

item.description:
When you die, you can take it with you!

Take on the role of Egyptian nobles at the time of the pharaohs, preparing for death and burial in the Valley of the Kings. Players want to fill their tombs with food, canopic jars, statues, amulets and other treasures, and to do so they acquire cards that are laid out in the shape of a pyramid; purchase cards at the base of the pyramid, and it "crumbles" to bring cards higher in the pyramid to the base where they can be bought. The pyramid resets each round with new offerings.

You score only for cards that you remove from your deck and stash in your tomb, so if you keep using valuable cards for their effects and don't entomb them before the game ends, you could lose out on big points! Whoever collects the most valuable artifacts in their tomb wins.

Valley of the Kings: Premium Edition includes all the cards from the three previously released games (Valley of the Kings, Afterlife, Last Rites), plus the components needed to play with a fifth and sixth player. It also includes rules for solo play, dividers for all the cards, and new pharaoh cards that give their holder unique abilities. The components are upgraded to 300+ tarot-sized cards.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Valley of the Kings: Last Rites

item.description:
EXFIL is a cooperative game for 4 players. You are members of Black Group, a special operations unit of military operators from around the globe. Black Group’s primary skills revolve around exfiltrating assets from difficult situations. It’s time to gear up!

EXFIL is a legacy campaign where your actions and decisions affect the course, landscape and difficulty of the game. You play as an Operator with a unique deck of cards that represent your skills. Over the course of each mission, you will need to make tough decisions involving managing your deck, managing Hostiles and fighting against the mission clock to complete objectives and reach the EXFIL point.

—description from the publisher

When the balance of the planet Malhya is threatened, a group of heroes wakes up...

You’re one of those heroes with extraordinary abilities. Mastering the power of the Aura, the energy of the planet, you will fill one by one the missions allowing to thwart the plans of the enemies put on your way.

In this great narrative adventure game of which you are the hero, you will be able to enjoy a complete experience, exploring regions as well as dungeons, your abilities will be tested at many events, you will be able to infiltrate, fight, craft, negotiate, solve riddles… but above all live a story that will be told according to your own choices.

Various scenarios (-3h+), miniatures, high replayability, you can save your run without blocking your material.

—description from the publisher

Bring big laughs to game night with Sketchagrams, the hilarious hashtag drawing game from the makers of Pictionary. Create the perfect social media-inspired picture to accompany odd pairs of hilarious captions and hashtags!

Pull one caption card and two hashtag cards, then you have forty-five seconds to draw a picture inspired by the combination. When the time is up, each player votes on which illustration they find the most outrageously funny and grant the artist a LIKE token. You don't have to be a pro artist to steal the round -- in fact, the less practiced illustrators often end up with the funniest result! The player with the most LIKE tokens after four rounds is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Tabletop miniature 10 pin bowling.

All the fun of 10 pin bowling only on a smaller scale! The objective is to knock down as many pins as possible. Each bowler has ten frames in which to knock down pins, with each frame being composed of up to two bowls.

Line up the aiming handle and push the marble down the alley. Skittles that are knocked over should be cleared off the alley before the second bowl. The crib can then be used to quickly and accurately set the skittles back for the next player.

—description from the publisher

A disc flicking version of classic billiards.

Use the triangle to rack the 15 billiard discs and flick the white cue disc to strike them. Basic pool rules apply, with the winner being the first to sink all seven of their billiard discs plus the number 8 disc. The felt covered gameboard rotates for easy tabletop playing and the woven string pockets ensure discs do not fall onto the floor.

—user summary

Flick, block and ricochet your way to victory. Strategically shape the ice to your benefit, then thread your way through your opponent's stones to get to the house. Be the first team to reach 11 points by ending rounds with stones closer to the target than the other team.

—description from the publisher

A travel-sized, dexterity, curling game for two players/teams.

Bring the fun of a classic Turkey Shoot to your table.

Players load their shotgun card with bird shot or a slug and take aim at classic turkey shoot targets. Tilt the back of the shotgun up to dump your bird shot or slug onto the target and see if you can get the best shot and win a turkey. Each turkey claimed is worth points depending on its weight. After 10 events the turkeys are weighed and the player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

A baseball/softball themed dice and card game.

There are three levels of gameplay: Rookie, Professional, and All-Star. The Rookie level is the basic level using only dice, while the other two levels add cards, which add levels of strategy. As a bonus, this game will teach you the game of baseball as you play. If you don't know baseball, it's still easy to learn Base Roll.

Each team uses three dice to roll combinations that move their players around four bases to score points. Using your dice and cards, you can affect rolls and block potential base hits, bunts, and even home runs!

The game lasts 9 rounds (innings) and the player with the most runs wins the game.

-description from publisher
